bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 24, 1922

div1.p: Hanson details the progress against yellow fever in Peru, but notes that the situation in Mexico and Central America is more serious than once thought.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 24, 1922
div1.opener:

HENRY HANSON

OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 -- TELEFONO ???
LIMA --- PERU
Jan. 24, 1922.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Dr. Carter,-
div1.p:
I have read with great interest your letter of January first. Although this
is considerably after January first we are still balancing our accounts and are
trying to get up a statement of our expenses up to the end of the year '21.
Either we are slow or we have a heap of accounts to balance- probably both.
Am glad to note what you say about Dr. Arce's theories. I could not see where
he had anything to back him up in his ridiculous statements about a Blackwater
fever which runs in epidemics and gives immunity. The Academy of Medicine
seems to have taken our point of view and voted him down to a man - he was the
only man in the Academy who voted against the diagnosis of yellow fever. They
even went so far as to suggest that there should be some further studies made
in regard to Fiebre billosa hemoglobinurica which he had reported some years ago.

In order that you may not entirely forget the family I am inclosing some
views of the “kiddies” we have taken lately. Martha often speaks of Dr. Carter.

In regard to what Col. White said about the soldiers who were vaccinated, I
presume that that is best answered in the reprint of Col. Vergne's article which
I sent you a few days ago. I do not remember the exact detail of which you speak,
of the 50 soldiers of whom 25 were vaccinated and 25 unvaccinated. However, we
did vaccinate, in the latter part of the epidemic, about 225 soldiers, and of
those vaccinated (although there still occurred cases in Lambayeque) we had no
cases among them. In Paijan, Dr. Tapia told me that so far as he knew there
were no cases among the persons who were vaccinated in Paijan.

In regard to Dr. Cross, I saw a notice of his death in the Comercio and later
received a letter from Dr. Rose telling me about the incident. He contracted
his fever at Tuxtepec, took sick there and was transferred to Vera Cruz. The
moving of him from Tuxtepec to Vera Cruz, in my mind, was the principal cause
of his death. In our experience we have had a very high mortality among
all cases which have been moved, and I have attempted to establish a very
rigid rule that no case of yellow fever be moved if there is any way to avoid
it. I am inclined to think that by proper care of cases the percentage of
deaths can be reduced very considerably. I failed to understand Dr. Noguchi's
line of reasoning in what you say of this vaccination. I do not see why the
fact of eleven days between the first and second doses should necessarily
neutralize the effect of the first dose. The only thing I can see is that
if he was bitten very shortly after the second dose, within the first few days,
when their might have been a possible negative phase immediately following
vaccination that this might have given rise to a temporarily lowered resistance
and made him more susceptible to infections temporarily. Very probably Noguchi
is right in the matter but I honestly cannot see it. I do not see that his
theory harmonizes with what I thought I knew about vaccinations and immunities
resulting there from. However, we will talk more about this when I see you in
New York in June.

In regard to your question about the value of vaccination, or rather data as
to the value of it, what I have mentioned in regard to Paijan and the troops

is about all I can tell you on that point. Of the eight soldiers who fell
sick and to whom curative serum was given, six of the eight recovered. These
soldiers were Cerranos. But the fact of the matter is that I have not had
time to stop and make accurate observations.

As to the name of the clerk at Duncan & Fox's, I presume it must be Miller
to whom you refer as he was the fourth one at the time we were there.

Mr. Wrightson's activities seem to be somewhat limited. The president
asked him recently to go and make an investigation in Paita, but Wrightson
suggested that he had better stay on in Lima until after his reorganization
bill had gone through Congress - to which the president replied that maybe
that was so, probably it would be as well if he stayed.

In so far as our work is concerned, it seems we are getting along well and
that we are going to finish the job. In order to know about this I have recently
sent Dunn, Olivari and Caballero south to Ica so that we shall have complete
data on all the coast; they will even go farther south than that and will be
gone about a month, investigating closely both for suspicious cases of illness
and stegomya breeding, and to some extent anophleles breeding.

The Rockefellers, recently, sent me a map of Mexico showing the distribution
of the disease there during the past two years, and I must say that after
looking that copy over the Mexicano-Central American situation looks much more
serious and unsettled than I had supposed that it was. The distribution is
rather annoying, at least it would be to me if I were in Dr. White's position
of General Director for the whole thing. It looks to me like a proposition
which cannot be finished in 1922 as I had previously expected and hoped would be

the case. It also looks to me like a situation where Dr. White needs several
very reliable and competent men as sub-directors for this campaign.

We are very sorry to hear that you are having trouble with your hip and
with your “kink” but are sincerely hoping that by the time this reaches you
you will be much better and quite yourself again.
